ETYMOLOGY: Reduplication of the English word 'so', which comes from Old English 'swā', meaning 'in that way' or 'to that extent'. The reduplication emphasizes a middling or indeterminate quality.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: An adjective is a word that describes or modifies a noun or pronoun.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Of moderate quality; neither particularly good nor bad; mediocre.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 质量平平；不好不坏；马马虎虎的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The food at the new restaurant was just so-so, nothing special.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 新餐厅的食物一般般，没什么特别的。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: An adverb is a word or phrase that modifies a verb, an adjective, or another adverb, indicating manner, place, time, or degree.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: In a mediocre or average way; neither well nor badly.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 一般地；马马虎虎地；不好不坏地。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: When asked how he was feeling, he just shrugged and said, 'So-so.'
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 当被问及感觉如何时，他只是耸了耸肩说：“一般般。”
